@article{zhang2019advantage,
	title = {Advantage of Being Multicomponent and Spatial: Multipartite Viruses Colonize Structured Populations with Lower Thresholds},
	author = {Zhang, Yi-Jiao and Wu, Zhi-Xi and Holme, Petter and Yang, Kai-Cheng},
	journal = {Physical Review Letters},
	volume = {123},
	issue = {13},
	pages = {138101},
	numpages = {6},
	year = {2019},
	month = {Sep},
	publisher = {American Physical Society},
	doi = {10.1103/PhysRevLett.123.138101},
	url = {https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.123.138101}}
abstract: Multipartite viruses have a genome divided into different disconnected viral particles. A majority of multipartite viruses infect plants; very few target animals. To understand why, we use a simple, network-based susceptible-latent-infectious-recovered model. We show both analytically and numerically that, provided that the average degree of the contact network exceeds a critical value, even in the absence of an explicit microscopic advantage, multipartite viruses have a lower threshold to colonizing network-structured populations compared to a well-mixed population. We further corroborate this finding on two-dimensional lattice networks, which better represent the typical contact structures of plants.
